dc:description:
The *ZSWIM6* gene is located at chromosome 5q12.1, has 14 exons, and encodes a 133.kDa protein that belongs to a group of proteins described by the SWIM-type zinc finger domain. Multiple disease entities have been reported in association with this gene. According to criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, there was evidence of differences in their molecular mechanism and phenotypic spectrum. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split into multiple disease entities: acromelic frontonasal dysostosis (OMIM:603671) and neurodevelopmental disorder with movement abnormalities, abnormal gait, and autistic features (OMIM:617865). Here, we curate autosomal dominant acromelic frontonasal dysostosis (MONDO:0011359).

*ZSWIM6* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant acromelic frontonasal dysostosis  in 2014 (Smith et al., 2014, PMID: 25105228). Patients with this disease have been identified as heterozygous for a de novo missense mutation (c.3487C>T, p.Arg1163Trp) in the *ZSWIM6* gene. Smith et al 2014 postulate a gain-of-function effect of the mutation because of the differing phenotype in individuals with heterozygous deletions of the gene versus those diagnosed with acromelic frontonasal dysostosis. Common phenotypes for individuals with this variant include large fontanelle, hypertelorism, bifid nasal tip, nasal clefting, brachycephaly, median cleft face, carp-shaped mouth, interhemispheric lipoma, tibial hypoplasia/aplasia, symmetric preaxial polydactyly of the feet, bilateral clubbed foot, thickened nails of halluces, and intellectual disability. Due to the multitude of cases with this rare and distinct phenotype and the de novo occurrence in a highly constrained gene, the expert panel decided to award an additional 0.4 points per proband who has radiographic imaging and/or publicly available images. 

One missense variant in three publications (PMID: 25105228, 26706854, 33776626) and four clinical testing laboratories (SCV000568856.6, SCV004011595.1, SCV000742103.4, SCV000986913.2) have been included in this curation. De novo status has been confirmed for 12 out of the 14 probands reported here. This gene disease relationship is also supported by expression studies and a knockout mouse model (PMIDs: 25105228, 28433741).
 
In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *ZSWIM6* and autosomal dominant acromelic frontonasal dysostosis. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings. This classification was approved by the Craniofacial Malformations Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 08/24/2023 (SOP Version 9).
curationReasonDescription: All patients with this disease share the same de novo missense mutation (p.Arg1163Trp) in the ZSWIM6 gene. Consequently, scores for probands with radiographic imaging and/or publicly available images were adjusted. Additionally, four clinical laboratory cases with clinical descriptions were incorporated into this curation.

evidence.dc:description: The scoring was reduced by 1.0 point for AFND-specific phenotype in the mice.

Zswim6 knockout mice exhibited increased neonatal lethality, with approximately 40% surviving until weaning. These mutant mice displayed a slight decrease in striatal volume, substantial reduction in the number of medium spiny neurons, and a significant decline in striatal dendritic arborization compared to control mice. Behavioral analysis of the mutant mice revealed impaired motor learning, mild hyperactivity, heightened sensitivity to amphetamine, and various other motor function abnormalities, indicative of striatal dysfunction. The study concluded that this mouse model could serve as a valuable tool for investigating the functional roles of Zswim6 in the development of the nervous system.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zswim6 KO mice

evidence.dc:description: Zswim6 displays a general low expression in early embryos, which continues until 24 hours post-fertilization (hpf). At this stage, its expression becomes more pronounced and localized in the telencephalon and midbrain. By 48 hpf, zswim6 expression in the telencephalon remains; however, increased expression is observed in the midbrain, hindbrain, and retina. These expression patterns are relevant to understanding the developmental roles of zswim6, with dlx2a cDNA serving as a reference in the in situ hybridization analysis.
evidence.rdfs:label: In situ hybridization

evidence.dc:description: IHC on embryonic day 13.5 (E13.5) and postnatal day 0 (P0) mice revealed widespread protein distribution within the central nervous system at both stages. At E13.5, the most distinct protein localization was observed in the lens fiber cells. In P0 mice, restricted protein localization was evident in the stereocilia of cochlear outer hair cells, a specific group of external root sheath cells in hair follicles, ameloblasts and odontoblasts and a subset of skeletal muscle cells
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunohistochemistry

dc:source.dc:abstract: Variant interpretted as pathogenic and reported on 09/20/2018 by GTR ID 239772. GenomeConnect assertions are reported exactly as they appear on the patient-provided report from the testing laboratory. GenomeConnect staff make no attempt to reinterpret the clinical significance of the variant.
dc:source.dc:creator: GenomeConnect, ClinGen
dc:source.dc:title: NM_020928.2(ZSWIM6):c.3487C>T (p.Arg1163Trp)

evidence.dc:description: The score was modified based on the highly-specific phenotype. Adjusted to 1.0.
The score was modified based on radiographic imaging(0.4) and the highly-specific phenotype. Adjusted to 1.25 for entry.
The score was modified based on damaging evidence from computational predictions, radiographic images, and the highly specific phenotype. Adjusted to 1.5 for entry.

In silico modeling predicts that a tryptophan substitution at p.arginine in ZSWIM6 would highly impact the protein due to disrupted interactions with functional residues. An atomic model further suggests that this substitution at Arg1163, located on the protein surface between charged residues likely involved in protein-protein interactions, would be highly disruptive.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Not observed at significant frequency in large population cohorts (gnomAD); In silico analysis supports that this missense variant has a deleterious effect on protein structure/function; This variant is associated with the following publications: (PMID: 25105228, 33776626, 26706854)
dc:source.dc:creator: GeneDx
